description: Enterprise techniques used by RedLeaves, ATT&CK software S0153 v1.0
name: RedLeaves (S0153)

techniques.comment: RedLeaves can receive and execute commands with cmd.exe. It can also provide a reverse shell.[1][2]
RedLeaves uses a specific port of 443 and can also use ports 53 and 80 for C2. One RedLeaves variant uses HTTP over port 443 to connect to its C2 server.[1][3]
RedLeaves can gather browser usernames and passwords.[3]
RedLeaves can communicate to its C2 over TCP using a custom binary protocol.[2]
RedLeaves is launched through use of DLL search order hijacking to load a malicious dll.[2]
RedLeaves can enumerate and search for files and directories.[1][2]
A RedLeaves configuration file is encrypted with a simple XOR key, 0x53.[1]
RedLeaves attempts to add a shortcut file in the Startup folder to achieve persistence. If this fails, it attempts to add Registry Run keys.[1][3]
RedLeaves is capable of downloading a file from a specified URL.[1]
RedLeaves attempts to add a shortcut file in the Startup folder to achieve persistence.[1][3]
RedLeaves can communicate to its C2 over HTTP and HTTPS if directed.[2][3]
RedLeaves has encrypted C2 traffic with RC4, previously using keys of 88888888 and babybear.[1]
RedLeaves can gather extended system information including the hostname, OS version number, platform, memory information, time elapsed since system startup, and CPU information.[1][3]
RedLeaves can obtain information about network parameters.[1]
RedLeaves can enumerate drives and Remote Desktop sessions.[1]
RedLeaves can obtain information about the logged on user both locally and for Remote Desktop sessions.[1]
RedLeaves can use port 995 for C2.[1]
